trans-unit.source: PowerShell
trans-unit.target: PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to create a SQL Database using PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to create a SQL Database using PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: To complete this article you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this article you need the following:

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you need an Azure subscription simply click **FREE TRIAL** at the top of this page, and then come back to finish this article.
trans-unit.target: If you need an Azure subscription simply click **FREE TRIAL** at the top of this page, and then come back to finish this article.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the Azure PowerShell modules by running the [Microsoft Web Platform Installer](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=320376&clcid=0x409).
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the Azure PowerShell modules by running the [Microsoft Web Platform Installer](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=320376&clcid=0x409).

trans-unit.source: For detailed information, see [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md).
trans-unit.target: For detailed information, see [How to install and configure Azure PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md).

trans-unit.source: The cmdlets for creating and managing Azure SQL Databases are located in the Azure Resource Manager module.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlets for creating and managing Azure SQL Databases are located in the Azure Resource Manager module.

trans-unit.source: When you start Azure PowerShell, the cmdlets in the Azure module are imported by default.
trans-unit.target: When you start Azure PowerShell, the cmdlets in the Azure module are imported by default.

trans-unit.source: To switch to the Azure Resource Manager module, use the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To switch to the Azure Resource Manager module, use the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: If you run the **Switch-AzureMode** and see warning: The *Switch-AzureMode cmdlet is deprecated and will be removed in a future release*, that's okay; just go to the next step to configure your credentials.
trans-unit.target: If you run the **Switch-AzureMode** and see warning: The *Switch-AzureMode cmdlet is deprecated and will be removed in a future release*, that's okay; just go to the next step to configure your credentials.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information, see [Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager](powershell-azure-resource-manager.md).
trans-unit.target: For detailed information, see [Using Windows PowerShell with Resource Manager](powershell-azure-resource-manager.md).

trans-unit.source: Configure your credentials and select your subscription
trans-unit.target: Configure your credentials and select your subscription

trans-unit.source: Now that you are running the Azure Resource Manager module you have access to all the necessary cmdlets to create a SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Now that you are running the Azure Resource Manager module you have access to all the necessary cmdlets to create a SQL database.

trans-unit.source: First you must establish access to your Azure account so run the following cmdlet and you will be presented with a sign in screen to enter your credentials.
trans-unit.target: First you must establish access to your Azure account so run the following cmdlet and you will be presented with a sign in screen to enter your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Use the same email and password that you use to sign in to the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Use the same email and password that you use to sign in to the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: After successfully signing in you will see some information on screen that includes the Id you signed in with and the Azure subscriptions you have access to.
trans-unit.target: After successfully signing in you will see some information on screen that includes the Id you signed in with and the Azure subscriptions you have access to.

trans-unit.source: Select your Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: Select your Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: To select the subscription you need your subscription Id.
trans-unit.target: To select the subscription you need your subscription Id.

trans-unit.source: You can copy it from the previous step, or if you have multiple subscriptions you can run the **Get-AzureSubscription** cmdlet and copy the desired subscription information from the resultset.
trans-unit.target: You can copy it from the previous step, or if you have multiple subscriptions you can run the **Get-AzureSubscription** cmdlet and copy the desired subscription information from the resultset.

trans-unit.source: Once you have your subscription run the following cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Once you have your subscription run the following cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: After successfully running **Select-AzureSubscription** you are returned to the PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: After successfully running **Select-AzureSubscription** you are returned to the PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one subscription you can run **Get-AzureSubscription** and verify the subscription you want to use shows **IsCurrent: True**.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one subscription you can run **Get-AzureSubscription** and verify the subscription you want to use shows **IsCurrent: True**.

trans-unit.source: Create a resource group, server, and firewall rule
trans-unit.target: Create a resource group, server, and firewall rule

trans-unit.source: Now you have access to run cmdlets against your selected Azure subscription so the next step is establishing the resource group that contains the server where the database will be created.
trans-unit.target: Now you have access to run cmdlets against your selected Azure subscription so the next step is establishing the resource group that contains the server where the database will be created.

trans-unit.source: You can edit the next command to use whatever valid location you choose.
trans-unit.target: You can edit the next command to use whatever valid location you choose.

trans-unit.source: Run **(Get-AzureLocation | where-object {$_.Name -eq "Microsoft.Sql/servers" }).Locations** to get a list of valid locations.
trans-unit.target: Run **(Get-AzureLocation | where-object {$_.Name -eq "Microsoft.Sql/servers" }).Locations** to get a list of valid locations.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to create a new resource group:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to create a new resource group:

trans-unit.source: After successfully creating the new resource group you see information on screen that includes **ProvisioningState : Succeeded**.
trans-unit.target: After successfully creating the new resource group you see information on screen that includes **ProvisioningState : Succeeded**.

trans-unit.source: Create a server
trans-unit.target: Create a server

trans-unit.source: SQL Databases are created inside Azure SQL Database servers.
trans-unit.target: SQL Databases are created inside Azure SQL Database servers.

trans-unit.source: Run **New-AzureSqlServer** to create a new server.
trans-unit.target: Run **New-AzureSqlServer** to create a new server.

trans-unit.source: Replace the ServerName with the name for your server.
trans-unit.target: Replace the ServerName with the name for your server.

trans-unit.source: It must be unique to all Azure SQL Servers so you will get an error here if the server name is already taken.
trans-unit.target: It must be unique to all Azure SQL Servers so you will get an error here if the server name is already taken.

trans-unit.source: Also worth noting is that this command may take several minutes to complete.
trans-unit.target: Also worth noting is that this command may take several minutes to complete.

trans-unit.source: You can edit the command to use any valid location you choose but you should use the same location you used for the resource group created in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: You can edit the command to use any valid location you choose but you should use the same location you used for the resource group created in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: When you run this command a window opens asking for a **User name** and **Password**.
trans-unit.target: When you run this command a window opens asking for a **User name** and **Password**.

trans-unit.source: This is not your Azure credentials, enter the user name and password that will be the administrator credentials you want to create for the new server.
trans-unit.target: This is not your Azure credentials, enter the user name and password that will be the administrator credentials you want to create for the new server.

trans-unit.source: The server details appear after the server is successfully created.
trans-unit.target: The server details appear after the server is successfully created.

trans-unit.source: Configure a server firewall rule to allow access to the server
trans-unit.target: Configure a server firewall rule to allow access to the server

trans-unit.source: Establish a firewall rule to access the server.
trans-unit.target: Establish a firewall rule to access the server.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command replacing the start and end IP addresses with valid values for your computer.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command replacing the start and end IP addresses with valid values for your computer.

trans-unit.source: The firewall rule details appear after the rule is successfully created.
trans-unit.target: The firewall rule details appear after the rule is successfully created.

trans-unit.source: To allow other Azure services to access the server add a firewall rule and set both the StartIpAddress and EndIpAddress to 0.0.0.0.
trans-unit.target: To allow other Azure services to access the server add a firewall rule and set both the StartIpAddress and EndIpAddress to 0.0.0.0.

trans-unit.source: Note that this allows Azure traffic from any Azure subscription to access the server.
trans-unit.target: Note that this allows Azure traffic from any Azure subscription to access the server.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure SQL Database Firewall](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee621782.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure SQL Database Firewall](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee621782.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Create a SQL database
trans-unit.target: Create a SQL database

trans-unit.source: Now you have a resource group, a server, and a firewall rule configured so you can access the server.
trans-unit.target: Now you have a resource group, a server, and a firewall rule configured so you can access the server.

trans-unit.source: The following command creates a new (blank) SQL database at the Standard service tier with an S1 performance level:
trans-unit.target: The following command creates a new (blank) SQL database at the Standard service tier with an S1 performance level:

trans-unit.source: The database details appear after the database is successfully created.
trans-unit.target: The database details appear after the database is successfully created.

trans-unit.target: Create a SQL database PowerShell script
